Welcome to 6.00.1x, Spring 2017!

UPDATE: Jan 15, 15:00: Grading queue is fixed.

UPDATE: Jan 15, 08:00: Grading queue is having issues processing submissions. edX has been alerted. We will update this page when we hear back from them. When the grading queue is fixed, we will reset everyones attempts back to 0 for Problem Set 1.

Courseware

At this time, you can access courseware (videos, problems, discussions, calendar, and a Progress tab to track your grade).

If this is your first time on the edX platform, please begin by viewing this welcome sequence that will cover important details on how to use the edX courseware and what to expect. You will be able to view course videos and problems under the Courseware tab (at the top left). If you are joining us again after taking a previous run of this course, we have updated the course videos and materials to Python 3.

Entrance Survey

Before starting on the courseware, we ask that you fill in the Entrance Survey -- we use your answers and feedback to improve the course!

Forum

There is a discussion board - accessible 24 hours a day - where you can get help from the course instructor, course TAs, as well as other students in the class. Please take the time to read our forum guidelines before posting (on the right).

Love helping others?

We would love to have community TAs for this course! If you know programming already and are dedicated and interested to help other students on the forum for the duration of this course, let us know by replying to this forum post. Guidelines for CTAs are available in a document on the right.

Handouts

Information about the class - including a syllabus and the course philosophy - are on the right. Please also take the time to look through all the course handouts we have provided for you on the right.

Take note that deadlines for this class will be stated in the UTC/GMT time zone. Take a look at the Calendar to familiarize yourself with them. You will have to convert times to your local time zone. What time is it in UTC right now? To see deadlines in your local timezone, go to your edX Dashboard settings and set the timezone (top right -> click the small arrow -> Account -> Timezone).

The deadline to sign up for an ID Verified Certificate from your edX Dashboard is Feb 7, 2017 at 23:30 UTC. The overall score you need to earn the certificate is at least 55%.

This page will be updated when a new lecture set and problem set comes out, approximately every week, and also when exams are available. This page is our best way of communicating important course updates and changes in a timely manner. To keep on top of the course, we urge you to visit it at least once a week.

Getting a Certificate

Note that edX does not offer Honor Code Certificates anymore. If you choose to audit the course, you will not get a certificate no matter what your overall score is. To get a certificate, you must click here to upgrade. The deadline to ID verify for a certificate is Feb 7, 2017 at 23:30 UTC.

Credit from Charter Oak

If you have upgraded to a verified certificate and pass the course with 65% or more, you will be eligible for credit through Charter Oak.

Social Media

Our Official Facebook Page
Our Official Facebook Group
Our Official Twitter Page @mitx6001x #mitx6001x
Our Slack Channel (see Discussion board)
Our plug.dj Private Room (to listen and play music with other learners as you study!)
Our Coding Sessions page on Google Plus

We hope you enjoy!

The faculty and course staff are looking forward to working with you this term, and we hope that you will have a great time learning about programming and computation. We are excited to have you all join us!

- Ana and the 6.00.1x staff

Week 2

[Graders back up: Sept 13 02:30 UTC] Graders are back up.
[Graders Down: Sept 13 00:30 UTC] EdX has been notified. We will update this when we know more!

UPDATE: As you may know, we offer optional study groups on MIT’s Unhangouts. To help you out with psets currently out, we will be holding two official study sessions this weekend! Community TAs and staff will be online to answer your pset questions.

  • Saturday Sept 10 at 13:00 UTC
  • Saturday Sept 10 at 20:00 UTC

Join us here!

We hope you are enjoying the course so far! We have released the next set of materials:

  • Lectures on Simple Algorithms and on Functions
  • Problem Set 2 will test you on coding up some simple algorithms applied to a real-life problem and is due Tuesday Sept 27 at 23:30 UTC.
  • Problem Set 1 is already out and due Tuesday Sept 20 at 23:30 UTC.

Take note that these deadlines are stated in UTC. To see deadlines in your local timezone, go to your edX Dashboard settings and set the timezone (top right -> click the small arrow -> Account -> Timezone).

If you are new to programming, you may find the following resources helpful:

  • the Python Tutor as a way to step through code (to understand and debug)
  • numerous other resources

For extra practice, we offer a set of "complete programming experiences" in the Courseware. You will write code that will be autograded for correctness and then be graded by your peers for coding style!

Happy coding!

Week 3

UNHANGOUTS Update: We had a good turnout the first time we did it, so we will hold it every Saturday until the course ends, except for weekends during the quiz and final exam! Community TAs and staff will be online at 13:00 UTC and 20:00 UTC (for about an hour, each time). Join us here!

New lectures are out! This week, we will look at new data types: lists and dictionaries. With these two objects, you will be able to write more interesting and involved programs. Problem Set 3, due on Tuesday Oct 11 at 23:30 UTC, will test your knowledge of these objects and you will implement a hangman game!

Remember that this course will challenge your ability to think critically. Lectures introduce you to concepts. Problem Sets simulate how it would be to solve programming problems and code in real life -- you will have to use the hints we give you, other online resources, and you will have to take breaks to give your brain a chance to absorb the problem.

Everyone can benefit from the course discussion forum -- you are not alone! We have community TAs (students just like you!) who have been through this already and are volunteering their time to help you succeed as well.

  • if you feel frustrated, take a few breaths and read this motivating post from your fellow student
  • re-read the course philosophy -- if you succeed in this course, it is a great achievement!
  • we have other social networks if you do not want to use the course forum: Facebook Group and Slack (see right hand side)
  • use the Python Tutor to step through your code

Finally, we would like to make a small correction regarding a grading policy inconsistency:

  • to receive a Verified Certificate, you need at least 55% overall
  • if you are taking this course for credit (Charter Oak, for example), you must be signed up for a Verified Certificate and achieve at least 65% in the course.
  • you can switch to/from a certificate on Tuesday Oct 4 at 23:30 UTC

Please give us any feedback you may have at any point in this forum thread.

No Materials

No new materials out this week. Catch up on your problem sets!

Week 4 and Quiz Information

The next set of materials are out: lectures on debugging, exceptions, and assertions. Problem Set 4, where you will implement a word game is also available.

Upcoming deadlines:

  • Problem Set 2, due Tuesday September 27 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 3, due Tuesday October 11 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 4, due Tuesday October 18 at 23:30 UTC
  • Switch to/from Verified Certificate, Tuesday Oct 4 at 23:30 UTC
  • Quiz available from Friday Sept 30 to Tuesday Oct 4 at 23:30 UTC, more info below

Quiz Information

  • The quiz will be available starting from Friday Sept 30 at 14:00 UTC.
  • The quiz will close on Tuesday Oct 4 at 23:30 UTC.
  • The quiz has no time limit, but you must submit your answers before the deadline.

Materials:

The quiz covers everything (video lectures, finger exercises, and problem sets) up to and including Lecture 7 on Debugging. You can use the textbook. You can use the internet to look up documentation and to clarify your knowledge of certain topics, as long as you are not deliberately looking up answers to the questions.

Practice:

We do not post practice exams, but you can check out the textbook finger exercises or MIT OpenCourseware for more coding practice questions. Also check out the Additional Python Resources for fun websites.

If you are still struggling with some concepts, check out a few optional tutorial videos on our Youtube channel for some of the more confusing topics in the course.

  • on strings
  • on tuples, lists, and mutability
  • on dictionaries and aliasing
  • on variable scope
  • on importing modules and indentation

During the Quiz:

The format will be some multiple choice and some coding questions. You can start anytime and you will only receive a grade for whatever you submit before the quiz deadline. For multiple choice questions, you will only have one try to submit. For coding questions, hit Save to save what you have written so far and hit Check to submit to the grader. You will only have 10 tries to submit code. We limit this number so that the graders do not get overloaded with so many submissions in such a short period of time. Please do not discuss the quiz on any of our social networks.

Check the Course Home page periodically. It is by far the fastest way the staff has to communicate delays, corrections, and changes. The forum is closed during the quiz. You can see past posts but not ask questions.

Wishing success to everyone!

Quiz Closed

Hint on Problem 8. If you got 18/20 and think you have the right code, consider any stylistically redundant parts in your code -- specifically, are you checking whether some boolean expression == True or == False? Your number of attempts for this question have been reset.

Week 5

In this week's lecture set, you will be learning about object oriented programming and classes. This is a tough concept to grasp, so make sure you do the finger exercises for practice! In Problem Set 6 you will be using what you learned to code a Caesar cipher to encrypt and decrypt secret messages!

Deadlines coming up:
  • Problem Set 3 is due next week on Tuesday October 11 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 4 is due on Tuesday October 18 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 5 is due on Thursday October 27 at 23:30 UTC

Week 6

The next set of lectures is more theoretical than what we have been doing so far. We will be looking at the efficiency and complexity of programs. Additionally, we will look at algorithms to search and sort lists. There is a final non-coding problem set up.

Upcoming deadlines:

  • Problem Set 4 is due next week on Tuesday October 18 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 5 is due on Thursday October 27 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 6 is due on Thursday October 27 at 23:30 UTC

Week 7

The final lecture set is available, on using a Python library to plot graphs of data.

Upcoming deadlines:

  • Problem Set 5 is due on Thursday October 27 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 6 is due on Thursday October 27 at 23:30 UTC
  • Final Exam on Friday Oct 28 to Tuesday Nov 1 (more details next week)

We have a few announcements as we are wrapping up the course:

  • The final exam will be available at the end of this week -- information is below
  • Problem Set 5 is due Thursday October 27 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 6 is due Thursday October 27 at 23:30 UTC
  • We have Python Revision Notes available to help you as you do the final exam
  • We have supplementary tutorial videos on some key concepts in the course on our Youtube page

Exam Information

  • The exam will be available starting from Friday October 28 at 14:00 UTC
  • The exam will close on Tuesday Nov 1 at 23:30 UTC
  • The exam has no time limit, but you must submit your answers before the deadline

Materials:

The exam covers everything (video lectures, finger exercises, and problem sets) in the course. You can use the textbook. You can use the internet to look up documentation and to clarify your knowledge of certain topics, as long as you are not deliberately looking up answers to the questions.

Practice:

We do not post practice exams, but you can check out the textbook finger exercises or MIT OpenCourseware for more coding practice questions. Also check out the Additional Python Resources from the Home page.

During the Exam:

The format will be some multiple choice and some coding questions. You can start anytime and you will only receive a grade for whatever you submit before the exam deadline. For multiple choice questions, you will only have one try to submit. For coding questions, hit Save to save what you have written so far and hit Submit to submit to the grader. You will only have 10 tries to submit code. We limit this number so that the graders do not get overloaded with so many submissions in such a short period of time. Please do not discuss the exam on the Facebook/Slack group page.

Check the course Home page periodically. It is by far the fastest way the staff has to communicate delays, corrections, and changes. The forum is closed during the exam. You can see past posts but not ask questions.

Wishing success to everyone!

Welcome to MITx 6.0001!

Mandatory Finger Exercises: You will use this site to complete finger exercises. Optional finger exercises are for extra practice -- they will have weights associated with them but will not count towards your grade. Mandatory finger exercises will be available for almost every lecture and will be due by the beginning of the following lecture (3pm). They will be mostly short coding and some non-coding and are worth 10% of your grade in this class. Please check the Stellar Calendar for lectures that have mandatory finger exercises and their corresponding due dates.

Stellar: The most up-to-date information about the class is on Stellar.

Online Discussions: We will use Piazza for all online discussions and questions you may have outside of recitations and office hours.

Videos on MITx: The videos on this site may not follow the lectures in class exactly. You do not have to watch the lectures here, and we are providing them in case you would like another take on the material.

The faculty and course TAs are looking forward to working with you this term, and we hope that you will have a great time learning about programming and computation. We are excited to have you all join us!
